text: I think we've lived in every kind of
society um for a lot of our existence as
human beings we've lived in Fairly
egalitarian hunter gatherer societies
but we've also lived in very
hierarchical t tyrannies as well so we
clearly can can manage to exist in both
and develop all kinds of different
societies why why hierarchy seems to
matter why status differences matter so
much and so the gap between rich and
poor matters is because as human beings
we're very sensitive to social
relationships you know we have an
evolved psychology um that makes us very
aware of how others judge us um if you
think about it some of the most
difficult things to do or or the most um
potentially embarrassing situations
we're in are those where other people
can judge us negatively
something rather like what I'm doing now
you know which might go out and be seen
by by hopefully thousands of people and
they might think I'm doing a good job or
a bad job and being aware of that can
make us very um feel very embarrassed um
be very aware of how others judges and
that really affects our um our
psychology and our biology in very
profound ways so if we're looking at
societies where the social distances
between people are bigger as they are in
more unequal societies there's just more
potential for all of us to feel that
we're judged negatively by others and to
feel that our status really matters that
it's really
important social evaluative threat yes
um that's the term psychologists use and
there are two psychologists who looked
at all the studies that other
researchers have done on what kind of
stresses most reli ibly um raise our
cortisol levels what kind of stresses
most reliably stress us and they usually
um do this kind of work by inviting
students into a laboratory and asking
them to do unpleasant tasks um they
might ask them to solve math problems or
to write about an unpleasant experience
or be videotaped doing something and the
question these researchers asked was
which kind of stress is most reliably um
raise our stress hormone levels and they
found it was ones which contain a social
evaluative threat so it's not so much
having to do math problems it's having
to read out your your marks at the end
and your scores and share them with
other people um it's tasks in which
other people can judge you negatively
that most reliably um make you feel
stressed it's
really well in our modern societies we
don't really need to consume more stuff
for basic survival rival um we consume
we shop we want to earn more money to
show our
status um and so owning things that
demonstrate that you know we're keeping
up um keeping up appearances um that
show that we're a valued member of
society that's that's why we consume so
much and in more unequal
societies that competition for status is
more important and so in more unequal
societies there is a a stronger drive
towards status competition and
consumerism all of those things matter
more you know it matters more to earn
more money not because you need more
money um for basic things but because
you need to sort of show your your state
is relative to other people in society
